channel.title: NYT > U.S.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Did Obama’s Bill Fix Veterans’ Heath Care? It’s Complicated.
item.media:description: An Army veteran, Henry Banks Sr., waited for prescription drugs at a Veterans Affairs medical center in Fayetteville, N.C., in March 2015.
item.description: A breakdown of the changes that were required under the Veterans Access, Choice and Accountability Act of 2014, and how some have faltered.
item.dc:creator: DAVE PHILIPPS

item.title: Boston Police Chief on Defusing Tensions: Relationships Matter
item.media:description: Boston’s police commissioner, William B. Evans, left, during a “peace walk” through the Roxbury neighborhood last month.
item.media:credit: Kayana Szymczak for The New York Times
item.description: Commissioner William B. Evans’s leadership style and close ties with minority communities have helped keep police-related violence in Boston to a minimum.
item.dc:creator: KATHARINE Q. SEELYE

item.title: For Anne Holton, Tim Kaine’s Wife, Elite Circles Are Old Turf
item.media:description: Anne Holton, who is married to the Democratic vice-presidential nominee, Senator Tim Kaine, at a rally on Monday in Richmond, Va.
item.media:credit: Chet Strange for The New York Times
item.description: She has lived since childhood in a world of politics and power, but relatives and friends describe her as being uncommonly unimpressed by the trappings of privilege.
item.dc:creator: JASON HOROWITZ

item.title: College Students Protest, Alumni’s Fondness Fades and Checks Shrink
item.media:description: A mural of Woodrow Wilson in the Wilson College dining hall at Princeton University, which has been removed. Protesters have unsuccessfully called for the removal of Wilson’s name from university buildings and programs.
item.media:credit: Mark Makela for The New York Times
item.description: A backlash from alumni is an unexpected aftershock of recent campus disruptions, as some colleges have reported a decline in donations and a rise in complaints.
item.dc:creator: ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS

item.title: Paul Ryan’s Rival, a Long Shot, Tries to Gain an Edge From Donald Trump’s Praise
item.media:description: Paul Nehlen, who is challenging Speaker Paul D. Ryan in the Republican primary, in May talked with Mary Ruffolo in Pleasant Prairie, Wis.
item.description: Paul Nehlen is capitalizing on an opportunity to benefit from an intraparty feud.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS FANDOS

item.title: The Innovation Campus: Building Better Ideas
item.media:description: Transparency’s the thing. Lassonde Studios, a live/learn building opening this month at the University of Utah, features glass-walled spaces on each residential floor.
item.description: Can architecture spur creativity? Universities are investing in big, high-tech buildings in the hope of evoking big, high-tech thinking.
item.dc:creator: ALEXANDRA LANGE

item.title: Vexing Question on Patient Surveys: Did We Ease Your Pain?
item.media:description: Dr. S. Michael Keller, a physician at the Marion General Hospital in Indiana, said that after his emergency department issued guidelines to limit the prescription of opioids, patients retaliated by giving the poor satisfaction scores in customer surveys.
item.media:credit: James Brosher for The New York Times
item.description: Doctors suggest that the link between patient satisfaction scores and Medicare reimbursements could lead to the over-prescription of addictive painkillers.
item.dc:creator: JAN HOFFMAN and SABRINA TAVERNISE

item.title: Your Money Adviser: Back-to-School Sales Tax Holidays May Be Skimpier This Year
item.description: Some states are scaling back or even ending the popular tax policy that gives families a small break as their children head back to school.
item.dc:creator: ANN CARRNS
item.category: Institute on Taxation and Economic Policy

item.title: Chip Credit Cards for Dummies (That’s All of Us)
item.media:description: Chip-enabled credit cards are being used more often in the United States, but lots of consumers are expressing frustrations with them.
item.media:credit: Bryan Anselm for The New York Times
item.description: Swipe the card. Nope. Dip the card? Maybe. Feel like an idiot? Definitely.
item.dc:creator: KAREN WORKMAN

item.title: The 2016 Race: How Donald Trump’s ‘Rigged’ Claim Chips Away at Democracy
item.media:description: Eight days after the 1960 election, they were still counting ballots in California in the race between John F. Kennedy and Richard Nixon.
item.description: Questioning the integrity of the system could undermine public confidence in elections.
item.dc:creator: BRENDAN NYHAN

item.title: Cory Booker, After Touring a Prison, Renews Call for Criminal Justice Overhaul
item.media:description: Senator Cory Booker of New Jersey at a news conference in Washington last month.
item.description: The New Jersey senator said that though he was determined to push for legislation cutting mandatory minimum sentences, he was not confident it would move this year.
item.dc:creator: CARL HULSE

item.title: The 2016 Race: Why a Meaningful Shift in the Trump-Clinton Race May Be at Hand
item.media:description: Hillary Clinton campaigning in Denver on Wednesday. It has been a week of good polls for her.
item.description: Polling suggests Hillary Clinton is benefiting from support from Bernie Sanders’s backers, and from Donald Trump’s self-induced wounds.
item.dc:creator: NATE COHN

item.title: Hillary Clinton to Address a Rare Audience: Journalists
item.media:description: Hillary Clinton speaking at a campaign rally in Pittsburgh on Saturday.
item.description: Mrs. Clinton, who speaks frequently to black and Latino groups but has given only a few news conferences, will deliver remarks to an annual convention of minority journalists.
item.dc:creator: AMY CHOZICK

item.title: Transgender on the Force
item.media:description: Officer Aiden Budd began his gender transition in the year before he started at the Police Academy in 2015. ‘I remember asking God a couple of times as a child why I wasn’t born a boy,’ he said.
item.media:credit: Sam Hodgson for The New York Times
item.description: Police officers coming to terms with their gender identity said they faced a dilemma of living what feels like a fraudulent life or risked being rejected from the tight-knit fellowship of law enforcement.
item.dc:creator: RICK ROJAS

item.title: Mark Kirk in Electoral Vise as Republican in Illinois Senate Race
item.media:description: Senator Mark S. Kirk at a news conference last month in Chicago. He became the first member of Congress to rescind his endorsement of Donald J. Trump.
item.media:credit: Alyssa Schukar for The New York Times
item.description: Mr. Kirk is among Republican incumbents who want to put distance between themselves and Donald Trump, but in doing so, they risk alienating base voters.
item.dc:creator: DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: As Trump Rises, ‘Reformocons’ See Chance to Update G.O.P.’s Economic Views
item.media:description: Donald J. Trump greeted supporters at a rally in Denver on July 29.
item.media:credit: Nick Cote for The New York Times
item.description: Conservative thinkers have felt emboldened to press their party to reshape its canon to more directly benefit the workers it has often taken for granted.
item.dc:creator: JACKIE CALMES

item.title: Dylann Roof Attacked by a Fellow Inmate, Officials Say
item.media:description: Dylann Roof being escorted from the Cleveland County Courthouse in Shelby, N.C., last year.
item.description: Mr. Roof, the white man charged in the massacre of nine black parishioners at a Charleston, S.C., church, was said to have been assaulted by a black man.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTOPHER MELE

item.title: Obama Disputes Claim of ‘Rigged’ Contest
item.description: Asked by a reporter to respond to Donald J. Trump’s accusations that the election was “rigged," President Obama said the claim was “ridiculous.”

item.title: Steven LaTourette, Congressman Who Despised Gridlock, Dies at 62
item.media:description: Steven C. LaTourette, a Republican congressman from Ohio, on Capitol Hill in 2009.
item.description: Mr. LaTourette, a centrist Ohio Republican, retired after nine terms in Congress because he was disgusted with Tea Party insurgents.
item.dc:creator: SAM ROBERTS

item.title: Spraying Begins in Miami to Combat the Zika Virus
item.media:description: Dr. Thomas R. Frieden, the director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, at a news conference in Florida on Thursday.
item.description: Officials said initial results showed a large number of mosquitoes were killed in a part of the city where a dozen locally transmitted cases had been reported.
item.dc:creator: LIZETTE ALVAREZ and PAM BELLUCK
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

item.title: Debate Over Trump’s Fitness Raises Issue of Checks on Nuclear Power
item.media:description: The president’s emergency satchel — a black briefcase full of war plans, authentication codes, and communication devices follows him (or her) just about everywhere, carried by an aide trained in the procedures.
item.media:credit: Clockwise from top left: Brooks Kraft LLC/Corbis, via Getty; Stephen Crowley/The NYT; Diana Walker/Time & Life Pictures, via Getty; Bettmann Archive/Getty; Diana Walker/Time & Life Pictures, via Getty; J. Scott Applewhite/AP; Ron Edmonds/AP
item.description: There are no checks on a president’s power to wage nuclear war, though history suggests that there may be ways to slow down or derail the process.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM J. BROAD and DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: Former Virginia Police Officer Convicted in Killing of Black Teenager
item.description: A white ex-officer was convicted of manslaughter with the jury recommending he serve two-and-a-half years in prison for killing an unarmed black man.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.category: Rankin, Stephen D (Portsmouth, Va, Police Officer)

item.title: Tax-Avoiding Mergers Find Champion in U.S. Chamber of Commerce
item.media:description: Representative Kevin Brady, a Texas Republican who is chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, has called the administration’s rules against tax inversions “damaging.”
item.description: The Chamber is leading a legal fight in Texas to overturn Treasury rules aimed at curbing mergers done for tax reasons.
item.dc:creator: LIZ MOYER and LESLIE PICKER

item.title: Arrested Protester of Baton Rouge Police Shooting Files Suit
item.media:description: DeRay Mckesson, a prominent figure in the Black Lives Matter movement, was arrested by the police in Baton Rouge, La., during a protest last month.
item.description: The suit by DeRay Mckesson says that the police “employed unconstitutional tactics to disturb, disrupt, infringe upon and criminalize” the rights of assembly and free speech.
item.dc:creator: CAMPBELL ROBERTSON

item.title: Another Airbag Maker Is Under Scrutiny After Fatal Rupture
item.description: A death in Canada was the first known fatality linked to a rupture in an airbag from a supplier other than Takata.
item.dc:creator: HIROKO TABUCHI

item.title: Bar Association Considers Striking ‘Honeys’ From the Courtroom
item.media:description: An opposing lawyer was fined and rebuked by a judge for making a sexist remark to Lori Rifkin, who said she was “well accustomed” to such comments.
item.media:credit: Jason Henry for The New York Times
item.description: An effort to bar sexist or discriminatory comments by lawyers addressing each other has been criticized for inhibiting the ability to speak freely.
item.dc:creator: ELIZABETH OLSON

item.title: Hillary Clinton to Animal Rights Protesters: Trumps ‘Have Killed a Lot of Animals’
item.media:description: Secret Service agents confronted animal rights activists at a Clinton rally in Las Vegas on Thursday.
item.description: Secret Service agents briefly surrounded the Democratic nominee as she was interrupted at a campaign event in Las Vegas.
item.dc:creator: TRIP GABRIEL

item.title: Obama Writes Feminist Essay in Glamour
item.media:description: President Obama and Michelle Obama with their daughters, Malia and Sasha, in 2015.
item.description: The president wrote a 1,500-word essay in the magazine, calling for equality and explaining that it was important to his daughters that he be a feminist.
item.dc:creator: DANIEL VICTOR

item.title: Phoenix Rattled as Serial Gunman Leaves 7 Dead and 2 Injured
item.media:description: A composite sketch of a possible suspect in a series of fatal shootings in Phoenix.
item.media:credit: Phoenix Police Department, via Associated Press
item.description: The authorities released a sketch of a man suspected of nine attacks and raised a reward for information to $50,000.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTINE HAUSER

item.title: 11-Year-Old Grills Mike Pence on ‘Softening Up’ Donald Trump’s Words
item.description: The Indiana governor was asked whether his role in a Trump administration would be to basically clean up after his commander in chief’s statements.
item.dc:creator: NOAH REMNICK

item.title: Donald Trump and Mike Pence Again Diverge on Endorsements
item.media:description: House Speaker Paul D. Ryan at the Republican National Convention last month in Cleveland.
item.description: Having already split with Mr. Trump over endorsing Paul Ryan, Mr. Pence told a Virginia television news station he would also support two snubbed Republican senators.
item.dc:creator: ALEXANDER BURNS and NOAH REMNICK

item.title: Questions and Answers on Voter Fraud
item.media:description: A voter arrived at the Oaklawn Language Academy in Charlotte, N.C., during the Super Tuesday primary contests in March.
item.media:credit: Travis Dove for The New York Times
item.description: Donald J. Trump, denouncing recent rulings against voter identification laws, suggested that fraud at the polls is common. Experts say that is wrong.
item.dc:creator: ALAN BLINDER

item.title: N.I.H. May Fund Human-Animal Stem Cell Research
item.media:description: A photomicrograph showing stem cells. The N.I.H. is considering changing the policy for funding experiments that include both human and animal stem cells.
item.description: The agency had banned funding for these kinds of experiments last September, but is reconsidering allowing some under strict conditions.
item.dc:creator: GINA KOLATA

item.title: With Billionaires Backing Her, Hillary Clinton Must Confront How to Deploy Them
item.media:description: The billionaire Mark Cuban at a campaign rally for Hillary Clinton in Pittsburgh on Saturday.
item.description: Members of the ultra-wealthy such as Mark Cuban, Warren E. Buffett and Michael R. Bloomberg are finding varied roles in a campaign focused in part on income inequality.
item.dc:creator: AMY CHOZICK

item.title: Cleveland Gets an Art Triennial
item.media:description: Visitors to Cleveland take in the skyline. A group of Cleveland boosters hopes to make the city a destination for art.
item.description: The city wants to attract visitors and international attention with contemporary art.
item.dc:creator: RANDY KENNEDY
item.category: Front International: Cleveland Exhibition for Contemporary Art
